DIV1.P: LONDON: PRINTED FOR J. ROBSON AT THE FEATHERS IN NEW BOND STREET.
TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE, LORD VISCOUNT NUNEHAM, THIS LITTLE POEM, AS AN OFFERING OF FRIENDSHIP, IS INSCRIBED, BY HIS AFFECTIONATE SERVANT

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: A tale that soft-ey'd Pity reads,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: The Spaniard left the hostile plain,
Beneath the sails that swept the main,

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Who as he met his country's foes,

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Yet not the early wreath of Fame
Nor pride nor fickleness could claim

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: The lowly hut, beneath whose roof

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: With hand profuse by her adorn'd

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: Her neat but homely garment press'd
Oft sought in vain behind the vest

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: "Ah know! for thee the heart that bled,

LG.HEAD: IX.
LG.L: "Blest moment to my wish that gives

LG.HEAD: XI.
LG.L: "Oft in the troubling dream of night

LG.HEAD: XIV.
LG.L: With look declin'd she blush'd consent—
And Love and Joy their influence lent

LG.HEAD: XV.
LG.L: The guests, to hail the wedded pair,
With them the little feast to share

LG.HEAD: XVI.
LG.L: Tho' no delicious wines were pour'd,
The hand-maid Neatness spread the board,

LG.HEAD: XVII.
LG.L: Scarce thro' one hasty week had Love
When bliss (as flies the frighted dove)

LG.HEAD: XVIII.
LG.L: Bad the youth rise to valor true,

LG.HEAD: XIX.
LG.L: But she still strained him to her heart,

LG.HEAD: XX.
LG.L: "How shall I chace the fears that say

LG.HEAD: XXI.
LG.L: "With thine my fate I now involve,
"No words shall shake my firm resolve,

LG.HEAD: XXII.
LG.L: "Fram'd for each scene of soft delight,
"As shrinks the lily at the blight,

LG.HEAD: XXIII.
LG.L: "And love, tho' falls the beating rain,

LG.HEAD: XXIV.
LG.L: But Nature's pow'rs subdued at length,

LG.HEAD: XXV.
LG.L: Three painful days unseen she lay
Of him she held so dear:
"Ah does he thus my love repay?

LG.HEAD: XXVI.
LG.L: "Ah wherefore did he vow true love,

LG.HEAD: XXVII.
LG.L: Stern pow'r with-held the tender youth,

LG.HEAD: XXVIII.
LG.L: To check the hand of Stealth,
That ravag'd wide th' encircling vine,

LG.HEAD: XXIX.
LG.L: To pass the line, it was ordain'd,

LG.HEAD: XXX.
LG.L: Soon to the brave CABEYSA prov'd

LG.HEAD: XXXI.
LG.L: Now MARY'S image haunts his soul,
While to his breast compassion stole,

LG.HEAD: XXXII.
LG.L: "For me a father's arms she fled—

LG.HEAD: XXXIII.
LG.L: "And now that health and peace forsake,

LG.HEAD: XXXV.
LG.L: "Now, now she weeps at my delay,

LG.HEAD: XXXVI.
LG.L: Soon at his sight the fair resum'd
On her pale cheek the rose rebloom'd,

LG.HEAD: XXXVII.
LG.L: Yet to that cheek return'd in vain
For bitter tears that cheek shall stain,

LG.HEAD: XXXVIII.
LG.L: The youth returning thro' the gloom

LG.HEAD: XXXIX.
LG.L: To meet his fate at wake of day
No weakness did his cheek betray,
While to the chief he said:

LG.HEAD: XL.
LG.L: "If in the battle death I've dar'd,
"Think not this scene, by thee prepar'd,

LG.HEAD: XLII.
LG.L: "Ah! when her grief-torn heart shall bleed,
"Oh guard her in the hour of need

LG.HEAD: XLIII.
LG.L: Now, kneeling on the fatal spot,
The twelve, who drew th'unwelcome lot,

LG.HEAD: XLIV.
LG.L: And now the murm'ring throng grew dumb,

LG.HEAD: XLV.
LG.L: Now, with their death-fraught tubes uprear'd,
And now the explosion dire was heard

LG.HEAD: XLVI.
LG.L: She comes! mark how her tortur'd mind

LG.HEAD: XLVII.
LG.L: "On me, on me your vengeance shed,

LG.HEAD: XLIX.
LG.L: Advancing now, she pierc'd the crowd,
Where, listing from the corse the shroud,

LG.HEAD: L.
LG.L: "His love for me the law defied,

LG.HEAD: LI.
LG.L: "When will the grave this form receive?
"There, only there I'll cease to grieve.
